revision.comment: That does not belong in the intro, and it is covered in the NOTES section
revision.text:
{{About|the Steve Jobs parody film|the journalist who uses "iSteve" as his online brand|Steve Sailer}} {{Use mdy dates|date=August 2016}} {{infobox film | name = iSteve | italic title = no | image = ISteve_Film_Poster.jpg | director = [[Ryan Perez]] | writer = Ryan Perez | starring = [[Justin Long]]
[[Jorge Garcia]]
[[James Urbaniak]]
[[Michaela Watkins]] | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = [[Funny or Die]] |distributor = [[Funny or Die]] | released = April 17, 2013 | runtime = 79 minutes | country = United States | language = English | budget = | gross = }}{{DISPLAYTITLE:''iSteve''}} '''''iSteve''''' is a 2013 [[parody film]] released on April 17, 2013{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2013/04/02/funny-or-die-steve-jobs-trailer/|title=Funny or Die's Steve Jobs Biopic Releases April 15|accessdate=April 17, 2013|date=April 2, 2013|publisher=[[Funny or Die]]|author=Erickson, Christine}} by producer [[Funny or Die]],{{cite web|url=http://tech.fortune.cnn.com/2013/04/17/review-funny-or-die-isteve/|title=Review: Funny or Die's 'iSteve'|access-date=April 17, 2013|date=April 17, 2013|work=[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]|author=Elmer-DeWitt, Philip|url-status=dead|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130418120442/http://tech.fortune.cnn.com/2013/04/17/review-funny-or-die-isteve/|archive-date=April 18, 2013|df=mdy-all}} marking their first full-length movie.{{cite web|url=https://variety.com/2013/digital/news/jobs-2-1200376470/|title=‘iSteve,’ Funny or Die’s First Long Form…Too Long?|accessdate=April 18, 2013|date=April 17, 2013|work=[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]|author=Marechal, AJ}} It claims to be the first biopic on the life of [[Steve Jobs]] after his death. The film stars [[Justin Long]], who had previously starred in Apple's ''[[Get a Mac]]'' ad campaign, as Jobs and [[Jorge Garcia]] as [[Steve Wozniak]].{{cite web|url=http://mashable.com/2013/04/17/funny-or-die-isteve/|title=Funny or Die's Steve Jobs Biopic 'iSteve' Debuts Online|accessdate=April 17, 2013|date=April 17, 2013|publisher=[[Funny or Die]]|author=Li, Anita}} The film was written in three days and shot in five by Ryan Perez, a former [[Saturday Night Live]] writer. ==Cast== ''In order of appearance'' {{colbegin|colwidth=30em}} *[[Justin Long]] as [[Steve Jobs]] *[[Jorge Garcia]] as [[Steve Wozniak]] *[[James Urbaniak]] as [[Bill Gates]] *[[Michaela Watkins]] as [[Melinda Gates]] *[[Jill Donnelly]] as [[Annie Leibovitz]] *[[John Ross Bowie]] as [[John Sculley]] *[[Joe Hartzler]] as [[Robert Palmer (computer businessman)|Robert Palmer]] *[[Charles Ingram (writer)|Charles Ingram]] as [[George Lucas]] *[[Andrée Vermeulen]] as [[D'arcy Wretzky]] *[[Paul Rust]] as [[Billy Corgan]] *[[Anthony Gioe]] as [[Justin Long]] *[[Joe Ferrell]] as [[John Hodgman]] *[[Nick Corirossi]] as [[Ben Curtis (actor)|Dell Dude]] *[[Kyle Mooney]] as Steve Jobs's Father *[[Gavin Pierce]] as Young Steve Jobs *[[Paul Walter Hauser]] as Pastey Jones {{colend}} ==Crew== *Directed by: [[Ryan Perez]] *Producer: [[Allison Hord]] *Written by: [[Ryan Perez]] *with additional material by: [[Danny Jelinek]], [[Anne Rieman]], [[Allison Hord]], [[Charles Ingram]], [[Nick Corirossi]] and [[Brad Schultz]] ==Critical review== As a free release on the Internet, the movie went unseen by film critics, with most public reactions coming from tech and business bloggers.{{cite web|url=http://www.rottentomatoes.com/search/?search=isteve&sitesearch=rt|title=Sorry, no results found for "isteve"|accessdate=May 3, 2013|publisher=[[Rotten Tomatoes]]}}{{cite web|url=http://www.metacritic.com/search/all/isteve/results|title=No search results found. Did you mean Steve?|accessdate=May 3, 2013|publisher=[[Metacritic]]}} According to ''[[Forbes]]'', early reviews are mixed. ''[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]'' reviewer Mat Honan stated that the movie was "profoundly unfunny" and that "If 'Funny or Die' is a promise, the crew should probably start coffin shopping."{{cite web|url=https://www.wired.com/underwire/2013/04/isteve-movie-review/|title=A Review of iSteve. Spoiler Alert: This Movie Sucks|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=April 17, 2013|work=[[Wired (magazine)|Wired]]|author=Honan, Mat}} Honan claims that the film has several inaccuracies but also notes that the film is a parody, which somewhat offsets that. [[CNET]] reviewer Amanda Kooser also notes that the movie "cut a few corners as far as accuracy goes".{{cite web|url=http://news.cnet.com/8301-17938_105-57580077-1/accuracy-schmaccuracy-isteve-props-go-hilariously-wrong/|title=Accuracy, schmaccuracy: 'iSteve' props go hilariously wrong: The makers of satirical Steve Jobs film "iSteve" take a liberal approach to computing and Apple history.|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=April 17, 2013|publisher=[[CNET]]|author=Kooser, Amanda}} Kooser notes that the film succeeded, in a sense, in beating [[Ashton Kutcher]]'s ''[[Jobs (film)|Jobs]]'' to market as the first Steve Jobs biopic after his death (''[[Pirates of Silicon Valley]]'' had been produced and released in 1999, 3 years after Jobs returned to Apple). Kooser also notes that the movie had rampant anachronistic technology term usage. ''[[Variety (magazine)|Variety]]'' reviewer AJ Marechal notes that the movie, which was written in three days and shot in five, "has its funny moments", but that it may be "too long", especially for the Funny or Die viewership. ''[[The New York Times]]'' critic Brooks Barnes described the movie as a "biopic poking fun at biopics" and said that writer Ryan Perez said "In true Internet fashion, it’s not based on very thorough research — essentially a cursory look at the Steve Jobs Wikipedia page".{{cite web|url=http://artsbeat.blogs.nytimes.com/2013/03/17/funny-or-die-makes-a-steve-jobs-movie/|title=Funny or Die Makes a Steve Jobs Movie|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=March 17, 2013|work=[[The New York Times]]|author=Barnes, Brooks}} Barnes also noted that the movie also bested a third Jobs movie in the works by [[Aaron Sorkin]] adapted from ''[[Steve Jobs (book)|Steve Jobs]]'' by [[Walter Isaacson]] with input from Wozniak to the market. ''[[Fortune (magazine)|Fortune]]'' reviewer Philip Elmer-DeWitt describes the movie as " an over-long Saturday Night Live skit that never quite gets rolling", but noted it had a few things going for it. [[Macworld]] reviewers Dan Moren and Lex Friedman provided one of the few positive reviews describing the movie as a humorous Jobs biography that "...is surprisingly amusing, provided you are both a fan of Apple and of stupid comedy, and presuming you also don’t mind a little profanity sprinkled in for good measure."{{cite web|url=http://www.macworld.com/article/2035456/review-funny-or-dies-isteve-will-tickle-apple-fans.html|title=Review: Funny or Die's iSteve will tickle Apple fans|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=April 17, 2013|publisher=[[Macworld]]|author=Moren, Dan and Lex Friedman}} ''Forbes'' reviewer noted that the scheduled April 15 release was delayed 2 days due to the [[Boston Marathon bombings]].{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/connieguglielmo/2013/04/17/funny-or-die-releases-steve-jobs-mockumentary-called-isteve/|title=Funny Or Die Releases Steve Jobs' Mockumentary Called 'iSteve'|accessdate=April 19, 2013|date=March 17, 2013|work=[[Forbes]]|author=Guglielmo, Connie }} ==Notes== {{Reflist|33em}} ==External links== *[http://www.funnyordie.com/videos/d2e0f617e3/isteve Official link] * {{IMDb title|2782834}} * {{Rotten Tomatoes|isteve}} {{Steve Jobs}} [[Category:2013 films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2010s parody films]] [[Category:Films about Steve Jobs]] [[Category:Funny or Die]]
